Jest to urządzenie, które pozwala na precyzyjną interakcję z obiektami w nanoskali. Taką definicję można przypisać zarówno małym robotom poruszającym się z nanometrową precyzją, jak i dużym urządzeniem, np. mikroskopowi sił atomowych. W niedalekiej przyszłości prawdopodobnie nanoboty będą mieć wiele zastosowań. W medycynie, nanoroboty mogą być użyteczne do identyfikowania komórek rakowych i ich niszczenia oraz prawdopodobnie, wprowadzone do organizmu byłyby wstanie znacznie wydłużyć czas życia naszego gatunku likwidując inne zagrożenia życia (choroby genetyczne) a nawet zapewnić nam nieśmiertelność (nieustanie "naprawiając" DNA- lecz to jedynie plotki). Innym potencjalnym zastosowaniem, jest detekcja toksycznych chemikaliów i pomiar ich koncentracji w środowisku.

TEXT.English: Nanogenerator is a technology that converts mechanical/thermal energy as produced by small-scale physical change into electricity. Nanogenerator has three typical approaches: piezoelectric, triboelectric, and pyroelectric nanogenerators. Both the piezoelectric and triboelectric nanogenerators can convert the mechanical energy into electricity. However, the pyroelectric nanogenerators can be used to harvest thermal energy from a time-dependent temperature fluctuation.
TEXT.Polish: Nanogeneratory to mikrogeneratory oparte o nanotechnologię.

TEXT.English: These structures can dynamically configures themselves on the molecular level. They are ideal for quick construction of space habitats.

A nanotruss is a carefully architected nanostructure made up of members that are as thin as five nanometers. They are constructed in such a way that it is possible to tune the material properties of the used materials in order to make the whole structure extra-resistant and extremely lightweight at the same time.
TEXT.Italian: Un nanotraliccio è una nanostruttura attentamente progettata, i cui componenti sono spessi fino a cinque nanometri. Sono costruiti in modo tale che sia possibile adattare le proprietà del materiale utilizzato per rendere l'intera struttura extra-resistente ed estremamente leggera allo stesso tempo.

TEXT.English: Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are allotropes of carbon with a cylindrical nanostructure. Nanotubes have been constructed with length-to-diameter ratio of up to 28,000,000:1, which is significantly larger than any other material. These cylindrical carbon molecules have novel properties that make them potentially useful in many applications in nanotechnology, electronics, optics and other fields of materials science, as well as potential uses in architectural fields. They exhibit extraordinary strength and unique electrical properties, and are efficient conductors of heat. Their final usage, however, may be limited by their potential toxicity. Nanotubes are members of the fullerene structural family, which also includes the spherical buckyballs. The ends of a nanotube might be capped with a hemisphere of the buckyball structure. Their name is derived from their size, since the diameter of a nanotube is on the order of a few nanometers (approximately 1/50,000th of the width of a human hair), while they can be up to several millimeters in length (as of 2008). Nanotubes are categorized as single-walled nanotubes (SWNTs) and multi-walled nanotubes (MWNTs). Carbon nanotubes are the strongest and stiffest materials yet discovered in terms of tensile strength and elastic modulus respectively. In 2000, a multi-walled carbon nanotube was tested to have a tensile strength of 63 gigapascals (GPa). This, for illustration, translates into the ability to endure weight of 6300 kg on a cable with cross-section of 1 square millimeter.

Natron is a naturally occurring mixture of sodium carbonate decahydrate and about 17% sodium bicarbonate (also called nahcolite or baking soda, NaHCO3) along with small quantities of sodium chloride and sodium sulfate. Natron is white to colourless when pure, varying to gray or yellow with impurities. Natron deposits are sometimes found in saline lake beds which arose in arid environments. Throughout history natron has had many practical applications which continue in the wide range of modern uses of its constituent mineral components. In modern mineralogy the term natron has come to mean only the sodium carbonate decahydrate (hydrated soda ash) which makes up most of the historical salt.

Natural gas is a fossil fuel formed when layers of buried plants, gases, and animals are exposed to intense heat and pressure over thousands of years. The energy that the plants originally obtained from the sun is stored in the form of chemical bonds in natural gas. Natural gas is a nonrenewable resource because it cannot be replenished on a human time frame. Natural gas is a hydrocarbon gas mixture consisting primarily of methane, but commonly includes varying amounts of other higher alkanes and sometimes a usually lesser percentage of carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and/or hydrogen sulfide. Natural gas is an energy source often used for heating, cooking, and electricity generation. It is also used as fuel for vehicles and as a chemical feedstock in the manufacture of plastics and other commercially important organic chemicals.

A fishing net or fishnet is a net that is used for fishing. Fishing nets are meshes usually formed by knotting a relatively thin thread. Modern nets are usually made of artificial polyamides like nylon, although nets of organic polyamides such as wool or silk thread were common until recently and are still used.
TEXT.Italian: Una rete da pesca è un dispositivo a maglie utilizzato per catturare i pesci; vengono realizzate legando in modo più o meno fitto i fili. Le reti moderne sono fatte in materiali sintetici come il nylon, anche se vengono ancora usate reti in lana o in seta.

TEXT.English: Brain implants, often referred to as neural implants, are technological devices that connect directly to a biological subject's brain - usually placed on the surface of the brain, or attached to the brain's cortex. A common purpose of modern brain implants and the focus of much current research is establishing a biomedical prosthesis circumventing areas in the brain that have become dysfunctional after a stroke or other head injuries. This includes sensory substitution, e.g., in vision. Other brain implants are used in animal experiments simply to record brain activity for scientific reasons. Some brain implants involve creating interfaces between neural systems and computer chips. This work is part of a wider research field called brain-computer interfaces. (Brain-computer interface research also includes technology such as EEG arrays that allow interface between mind and machine but do not require direct implantation of a device.)
TEXT.Polish: Neuroimplanty - urządzenie techniczne łączące się bezpośrednio z mózgiem ludzkim lub zwierzęcym zwykle umieszczone na powierzchni mózgu lub podłączone do kory mózgowej (implantowane elektrody domózgowe). Obecnie badania neurobiologów i inżynierów biomedycznych koncentrują się na zbudowaniu takich implantów mózgowych, które byłyby zdolne zastąpić obszary mózgu uszkodzone po udarze lub urazie mózgowym. Obejmuje to także zastąpienie czynności uszkodzonych układów czuciowych, np. wzrokowego (proteza wzroku). Inne implanty mózgowe są wykorzystywane w doświadczeniach na zwierzętach w celu bezpośredniej rejestracji czynności elektrycznej mózgu dla celów naukowych. Niektóre implanty mózgowe umożliwiają stworzenie interfejsu pomiędzy układem nerwowym i układem scalonym komputera, co jest częścią szerszych badań nad interfejsami mózg-komputer.

TEXT.English: Neutronium (sometimes shortened to neutrium) is a proposed name for a substance composed purely of neutrons. The word was coined by scientist Andreas von Antropoff in 1926 (before the discovery of the neutron) for the conjectured 'element of atomic number zero' that he placed at the head of the periodic table. However, the meaning of the term has changed over time, and from the last half of the 20th century onward it has been also used legitimately to refer to extremely dense substances resembling the neutron-degenerate matter theorized to exist in the cores of neutron stars; henceforth 'degenerate neutronium' will refer to this. Science fiction and popular literature frequently use the term 'neutronium' to refer to a highly dense phase of matter composed primarily of neutrons.

A newspaper is a periodical publication containing news regarding current events, informative articles, diverse features, editorials, and advertising. It usually is printed on relatively inexpensive, low-grade paper such as newsprint. By 2007, there were 6,580 daily newspapers in the world selling 395 million copies a day. The late 2000s-early 2010s global recession, combined with the rapid growth of web-based alternatives, caused a serious decline in advertising and circulation, as many papers closed or sharply retrenched operations.
TEXT.German: Das Wort Zeitung war ursprünglich der Begriff für eine beliebige Nachricht; die Bedeutung hat sich jedoch im Laufe des 18. Jahrhunderts geändert. Heute versteht man darunter ein periodisch erscheinendes Druckerzeugnis mit aktuellem und universellem Inhalt. Dieser besteht aus mehreren inhaltlich in sich abgeschlossenen Texten, die Zeitungsartikel genannt werden und bei deren Abfassung verschiedene journalistische Stilmittel angewandt werden.

TEXT.English: Because of nickel's slow rate of oxidation at room temperature, it is considered corrosion-resistant. Historically, this has led to its use for plating metals such as iron and brass, in chemical apparatus, and in certain alloys that retain a high silvery polish, such as German silver.
TEXT.Polish: Nikiel (Ni, łac. niccolum) - pierwiastek chemiczny z grupy metali przejściowych w układzie okresowym. Został odkryty w roku 1751 przez szwedzkiego chemika, Axela Cronstedta. W 1804 r. otrzymano go po raz pierwszy w stanie czystym. Przed naszą erą był używany w stopach z miedzią i cynkiem.

TEXT.English: The Nok culture appeared in Nigeria around 1000 BC and vanished under unknown circumstances around 300 AD in the region of West Africa. This region lies in Northern and Central Nigeria. Its social system is thought to have been highly advanced. The Nok culture was considered to be the earliest sub-Saharan producer of life-sized Terracotta. It has been suggested that the Nok culture eventually evolved into the later Yoruba Culture of Ife based on similarities seen in the artwork from these two cultures.

It is becoming increasingly clear that a large number of chemical companies have failed to manage and nurture their business models well enough. Research and development funds have dried up, and new molecular discoveries are increasingly rare. Few specialty chemical companies have demonstrated the ability or nimbleness to adjust to the new, much more difficult realities in the industry. How well these companies adopt one of three business models will determine success or failure for individual outfits and the industry as a whole.

Nutella is the brand name of a hazelnut chocolate spread. Manufactured by the Italian company Ferrero, it was introduced to the market in 1964. Nutella is made from sugar, modified palm oil, hazelnuts, cocoa, skimmed milk powder, whey powder, lecithin, and vanillin.
TEXT.German: Nutella ist ein süßer Haselnussbrotaufstrich des italienischen Herstellers Ferrero, der in Konsistenz und Geschmack an Nougat erinnert. Er besteht aus Zucker, Pflanzenöl, gerösteten Haselnüssen, Kakao, Milchpulver, Sojalecithin und Vanillin.

TEXT.English: A nut is a hard-shelled fruit of some plants having an indehiscent seed. While a wide variety of dried seeds and fruits are called nuts in English, only a certain number of them are considered by biologists to be true nuts. Nuts are an important source of nutrients for both humans and wildlife.
TEXT.Italian: Una noce è un frutto nel quale il frutto è protetto da un involucro duro. Anche se una grande varietà di frutti vengono chiamati noci in Inghilterra, non tutti sono vere noci secondo le definizioni dei biologi. Le noci sono una grande fonte di nutrienti, sia per gli uomini sia per gli animali.

TEXT.English: Nylon is a generic designation for a family of synthetic polymers known generically as polyamides, first produced on February 28, 1935, by Wallace Carothers at DuPont's research facility at the DuPont Experimental Station. Nylon is one of the most commonly used polymers.
TEXT.Italian: Nylon è il nome generico di una famiglia di polimeri sintetici conosciuti come poliamidi, prodotti per la prima volta il 28 febbraio 1935 da Wallace Carothers ad una stazione di ricerca della DuPont Experimental Station. Il nylon è uno dei polimeri usati più comunemente.

TEXT.English: Obsidian is a rapidly cooled felsic lava extruded from a volcano, with minimal crystal growth, resulting in a natural glass. Obsidian is hard, brittle, and amorphous; it therefore fractures with sharp edges. It can be used to make extremely sharp knives, blades, and even scalpel blades, with a cutting edge many times sharper than high-quality steel surgical scalpels. Obsidian is also used for ornamental purposes and as a gemstone. Pure obsidian is usually dark in appearance, though the color varies depending on the impurities present.
TEXT.Italian: L'ossidiana è una lava felsica rapidamente raffreddata estrusa da un vulcano, con una crescita minima di cristalli, che si traduce in un vetro naturale. L'ossidiana è dura, fragile e amorfa; si frattura quindi con spigoli molto affilati. Può essere utilizzato per realizzare coltelli, lame e persino lame per bisturi estremamente affilati, con un tagliente molte volte più affilato di quello dei bisturi chirurgici in acciaio di alta qualità. L'ossidiana è anche usata per scopi ornamentali e come pietra preziosa. L'ossidiana pura ha generalmente un aspetto scuro, sebbene il colore vari a seconda delle impurità presenti.
Permette a %s1_ImpName di esistere sul terreno
TEXT.Polish: Kwalifikuje %s1_ImpName do isntniena na danym polu

TEXT.English: Oil, also known as petroleum, is a naturally occurring, yellowish-black liquid found in geological formations beneath the Earth's surface. Petroleum is formed when large quantities of dead organisms, mostly zooplankton and algae, are buried underneath sedimentary rock and subjected to both intense heat and pressure. It consists of naturally occurring hydrocarbons of various molecular weights and may contain miscellaneous organic compounds. It is commonly refined into numerous consumer products, from gasoline (petrol) and kerosene to asphalt and chemical reagents used to make plastics, pesticides and pharmaceuticals. Its use as fuel, however, is one of the main causes of global warming and ocean acidification.
TEXT.Italian: Il petrolio è un liquido naturale di colore giallo-nero che si trova nelle formazioni geologiche sotto la superficie terrestre. Il petrolio si forma quando grandi quantità di organismi morti, principalmente zooplancton e alghe, vengono sepolte sotto la roccia sedimentaria e sottoposte a calore e pressione intensi. È costituito da idrocarburi naturali di vario peso molecolare e può contenere composti organici vari. È comunemente raffinato in numerosi prodotti di consumo, dalla benzina al cherosene, dall'asfalto ai reagenti chimici utilizzati per la fabbricazione di materie plastiche, pesticidi e prodotti farmaceutici. Il suo uso come combustibile, tuttavia, è una delle principali cause del riscaldamento globale e dell'acidificazione degli oceani.

TEXT.English: Olives are the fruits of the olive tree, a short and squat tree found in the Mediterranean Basin, the Arabian Peninsula, and southern Asia, that rarely exceeds 8-15 m (26-49 ft) in height. Olives are small drupes, 1–2.5 cm (0.39–0.98 in) long, thinner-fleshed and smaller in wild plants than in orchard cultivars. Olives are harvested in the green to purple stage, and are of major agricultural importance in the Mediterranean region as the source of olive oil, being one of the core ingredients in Mediterranean cuisine.
TEXT.Italian: Le olive sono i frutti dell'albero di olivo, un albero corto e tozzo che si trova nel bacino del Mediterraneo, nella penisola arabica e in Asia meridionale, che raramente supera gli 8-15 m di altezza. Le olive sono piccole drupe, lunghe 1-2,5 cm, a polpa più sottile e più piccole nelle piante selvatiche rispetto alle cultivar di frutteto. Le olive vengono raccolte quando hanno il tipico colorito da verde a viola e sono di grande importanza agricola nella regione mediterranea come fonte di olio d'oliva, essendo uno degli ingredienti fondamentali della cucina mediterranea.

TEXT.English: Olive oil is a liquid fat obtained by pressing whole olives. It is commonly used in cooking, for frying foods or as a salad dressing. It is also used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and soaps, and as a fuel for traditional oil lamps, and has additional uses in some religions. There is limited evidence of its possible health benefits. The composition of olive oil varies with the cultivar, altitude, time of harvest and extraction process. It consists mainly of oleic acid (up to 83%), with smaller amounts of other fatty acids including linoleic acid (up to 21%) and palmitic acid (up to 20%). Extra virgin olive oil is required to have no more than 0.8% free acidity and is considered to have favorable flavor characteristics.
TEXT.Italian: L'olio d'oliva è un grasso liquido ottenuto dalla spremitura di olive intere. È comunemente usato in cucina, per friggere cibi o come condimento per insalate. È anche usato per cosmetici, prodotti farmaceutici e saponi e come combustibile per le tradizionali lampade a olio e ha usi aggiuntivi in alcune religioni. Vi sono prove limitate dei suoi possibili benefici per la salute. La composizione dell'olio d'oliva varia a seconda della cultivar, dell'altitudine, del tempo di raccolta e del processo di estrazione. È costituito principalmente da acido oleico (fino all'83%), con quantità minori di altri acidi grassi tra cui acido linoleico (fino al 21%) e acido palmitico (fino al 20%). L'olio extra vergine di oliva deve avere un'acidità libera non superiore allo 0,8% ed è considerato avere caratteristiche aromatiche favorevoli.

TEXT.English: Olmec jade figurines are archetypical figurines made of jade, bearing the hallmarks and motifs of Olmec culture. These figurines are usually found in household refuse, ancient construction fill, and, outside the Olmec heartland, graves. The vast majority of figurines are simple in design, often nude or with a minimum of clothing, and made of local terracotta.
TEXT.Italian: Le figurine di giada olmeche sono figurine archetipiche, con i segni distintivi e i motivi della cultura olmeca, realizzate in giada. Queste figurine si trovano di solito nei rifiuti domestici, nell'antico riempimento di costruzioni e, fuori dal territorio olmeco, nelle tombe. La stragrande maggioranza delle figurine hanno un disegno semplice, sono spesso nude o con un abbigliamento minimo, e realizzate in terracotta locale.

TEXT.English: Omega fatty acids are polyunsaturated fatty acids that contain more than one double bond in their backbone. They are widely distributed in nature, being important constituents of animal lipid metabolism, and they play an important role in the human diet and physiology, despite their bodies are not able to independently synthesize them.
TEXT.Italian: Gli acidi grassi omega sono acidi grassi polinsaturi che contengono più di un doppio legame nella loro dorsale. Sono ampiamente distribuiti in natura, essendo importanti componenti del metabolismo lipidico animale e svolgono un ruolo importante nella dieta e nella fisiologia umana, nonostante i loro corpi non siano in grado di sintetizzarli in modo indipendente.

TEXT.English: Opium, or poppy tears, is dried latex obtained from the seed capsules of the opium poppy. Approximately 12% of opium is made up of morphine, which is processed chemically to produce heroin and other synthetic opioids for medicinal use and for illegal drug trade. The latex also contains the closely related opiates codeine and thebaine, and non-analgesic alkaloids such as papaverine and noscapine. In its legal uses, it is used (in controlled doses) for treatment of neuropathic pain and other forms of chronic pain, and on a smaller scale, to treat diarrhea.
TEXT.Italian: L'oppio, o lacrime di papavero, è il lattice essiccato ottenuto dalle capsule di semi del papavero da oppio. Circa il 12% dell'oppio è costituito da morfina, che viene poi elaborata chimicamente per produrre eroina e altri oppioidi sintetici per uso medicinale e per il commercio illegale di droghe. Il lattice contiene anche codeina e tebaina, oppiacei strettamente correlati, e alcaloidi non analgesici come papaverina e noscapina. Nei suoi usi legali, è usato (in dosi controllate) per il trattamento di dolori neuropatici, di altre forme di dolore cronico e, su scala ridotta, per il trattamento della diarrea.

TEXT.English: An organic computer is a computer composed of organic material such as living neurons. First theorized at the end of 20th century, organic computers are capable, in a way, of "thinking for themselves" because of the dynamic nature of neurons: unlike conventional materials which operate in binary (on/off), a neuron can shift between thousands of states, constantly altering its chemical conformation, and in the end having significant advantages for generating patterns and computing higher order functions like memory, arithmetic logic, and input/output operations.
TEXT.Italian: Un computer organico è un computer composto da materiale organico come neuroni viventi. Teorizzato per la prima volta alla fine del XX secolo, i computer organici sono in grado, in un certo senso, di "pensare da soli" a causa della natura dinamica dei neuroni: a differenza dei materiali convenzionali che operano in forma binaria (I/O), un neurone può variare tra migliaia di stati, alterando costantemente la sua conformazione chimica e presentando vantaggi significativi per la generazione di schemi e il calcolo di funzioni di ordine superiore come memoria, logica aritmetica e operazioni di input/output.

TEXT.English: An organic photonic cell, or organic photonic crystal, is an organic-based periodic optical nanostructure that affects the motion of photons in much the same way that ionic lattices affect electrons in solids. These cells can be fabricated for one, two, or three dimensions, and are basically used wherever light must be manipulated. Existing applications include thin-film optics with coatings for lenses, optical computers, nonlinear devices, and photovoltaic cells.
TEXT.Italian: Una cellula fotonica organica, o cristallo fotonico organico, è una nanostruttura ottica periodica a base organica che influenza il movimento dei fotoni nello stesso modo in cui i reticoli ionici influenzano gli elettroni nei solidi. Queste celle possono essere fabbricate in una, due o tre dimensioni e sono fondamentalmente utilizzate ovunque sia necessario manipolare la luce. Le applicazioni esistenti includono ottiche a film sottile con rivestimenti per obiettivi, computer ottici, dispositivi non lineari e celle fotovoltaiche.

TEXT.English: Orichalcum is an artisan composite that is treated with exotic electroweak technology. Several ingots found during early 21st century in an ancient shipwreck led to define it as an alloy primarily made from copper and zinc, with small percentages of nickel, lead, and iron. It has been mentioned in several ancient writings, including those related to the story of Atlantis.
TEXT.Italian: L'oricalco è un composito artigianale trattato con tecnologia elettrodebole esotica. Diversi lingotti trovati all'inizio del XXI secolo in un antico naufragio hanno portato a definirlo come una lega principalmente composta da rame e zinco, con piccole percentuali di nichel, piombo e ferro. È stato menzionato in numerosi scritti antichi, inclusi quelli legati alla storia di Atlantide.

TEXT.English: Ostrich feathers are one of the reasons why ostriches are farmed. Generally, an ostrich has whitish neck, head, and underparts, with a thick covering of black or dark-brown feathers crowning the entire back. The female's feathers are almost uniformly brown, while males have a black body with white wing and tail feathers. Ostrich plumes, especially the long ones from the birds' tail and wings, have been popular for centuries, primarily for use on hats. Today, their softness makes them useful for dusting and cleaning delicate parts in machinery.
TEXT.Italian: Le piume di struzzo sono uno dei motivi per cui gli struzzi vengono allevati. Generalmente, uno struzzo ha collo, testa e parti inferiori biancastri, con una spessa copertura di piume nere o marrone scuro che incoronano l'intera schiena. Le piume della femmina sono quasi uniformemente marroni, mentre i maschi hanno un corpo nero con ali bianche e piume di coda. I pennacchi degli struzzi, in particolare quelli più lunghi presenti sulla coda e sulle ali, sono stati popolari per secoli, principalmente per l'uso sui cappelli. Oggi, la loro morbidezza li rende utili per spolverare e pulire le parti delicate dei macchinari.

TEXT.English: Ostrich leather is a tanned skin distinctively recognized for its pattern of bumps or vacant quill follicles, ranged across a smooth field in varying densities. Its production process is intricate, specialised and expensive. Although the first commercial farming began in South Africa in mid-19th century, by 1920s the industry was already collapsed because of a drop in demand. Other products were marketed, with each success battered by world events and droughts until 21st century, when ostrich skin is globally seen as a luxury item in high-end demand.
TEXT.Italian: La pelle di struzzo è una pelle conciata riconoscibile per il particolare modello di protuberanze o follicoli di penna vuoti, che si estende su un campo liscio a varie densità. Il suo processo di produzione è complesso, specializzato e costoso. Sebbene le prime iniziative commerciali iniziarono in Sudafrica a metà del XIX secolo, negli anni venti del XX secolo l'industria era già crollata a causa di un calo della domanda. La commercializzazione ha continuato ad avere un andamento discontinuo fino al XXI secolo, quando la pelle di struzzo è stata considerata a livello globale come un oggetto di lusso di fascia alta.

TEXT.English: The papaya (from Carib via Spanish), papaw, or pawpaw is the fruit of the plant Carica papaya, the sole species in the genus Carica of the plant family Caricaceae. It is native to the tropics of the Americas, and was first cultivated in Mexico several centuries before the emergence of the Mesoamerican classical civilizations. The papaya is a large tree-like plant, with a single stem growing from 5 to 10 m tall, with spirally arranged leaves confined to the top of the trunk. The lower trunk is conspicuously scarred where leaves and fruit were borne. The leaves are large, 50-70 cm in diameter, deeply palmately lobed with 7 lobes. The tree is usually unbranched, unless lopped. The flowers are similar in shape to the flowers of the Plumeria, but are much smaller and wax-like. They appear on the axils of the leaves, maturing into the large 15-45 cm long, 10-30 cm diameter fruit. The fruit is ripe when it feels soft and its skin has attained an amber to orange hue. Carica papaya was the first fruit tree to have its genome deciphered.

Paper is a thin material mainly used for writing upon, printing upon, drawing or for packaging. It is produced by pressing together moist fibers, typically cellulose pulp derived from wood, rags or grasses, and drying them into flexible sheets.
TEXT.Italian: La carta è un mateiale sottile usato principalemnte per scrivere, stampare, disegnare o per gli imballaggi. Viene prodotta con la compressione di fibre vegetali, solitamente polpa di cellulosa derivata dagli alberi, che viene asciugata in fogli flessibili.

TEXT.English: The papyrus plant, Cyperus papyrus, a wetland plant that was once abundant in the Nile Delta of Egypt. The pith of the papyrus plant was used to make an early form of paper, papyrus, that was first known to have been used in ancient Egypt (circa 3050 BC), but it was also widely used throughout the Mediterranean region, as well as inland parts of Europe. The use of papyrus that was once common in Greece, Italy, and other regions of the ancient Mediterranean. However, the use of papyrus scrolls declined with the expansion of the use parchment (which was prepared from animal skins). By 800 AD the use of parchment and vellum had replaced papyrus in most of the Mediterranean, though its use in Egypt continued until it was replaced by more inexpensive paper introduced by Arabs.

In ancient times and currently parrot feathers have been used in ceremonies, and for decoration. In Polynesian legend as current in the Marquesas Islands, the hero Laka/Aka is mentioned as having undertaken a long and dangerous voyage to Aotona in what are now the Cook Islands, to obtain the highly prized feathers of a red parrot as gifts for his son and daughter. On the voyage a hundred out of his 140 rowers died of hunger on their way, but the survivors reached Aotona and captured enough parrots to fill 140 bags with their feathers. Parrots have also been considered sacred. The Moche people of ancient Peru worshipped birds and often depicted parrots in their art.

Interchangeable parts are parts that are, for practical purposes, identical. They are made to specifications that ensure that they are so nearly identical that they will fit into any device of the same type.
TEXT.Italian: I ricambi sono parti che vengono costruite identicamente, in serie, per usi pratici. Sono fatti in modo da funzionare esattamente in qualunque dispositivo per il quale vengono progettati.

TEXT.English: Pasta is a type of noodle and is a staple food of traditional Italian cuisine, with the first reference dating to 1154 in Sicily. It is also commonly used to refer to the variety of pasta dishes. Typically pasta is made from an unleavened dough of a durum wheat flour mixed with water and formed into sheets or various shapes, then cooked and served in any number of dishes. It can be made with flour from other cereals or grains, and eggs may be used instead of water. Pastas may be divided into two broad categories, dried (pasta secca) and fresh (pasta fresca). Chicken eggs frequently dominate as the source of the liquid component in fresh pasta.
TEXT.Polish: Makaron - produkt żywnościowy wytwarzany na bazie mąki, wody i niekiedy jaj (mówimy wtedy o makaronie jajecznym) oraz innych składników, o szerokiej gamie kształtów i zastosowań.

TEXT.English: A pearl is a hard, rounded object produced by certain mollusks, primarily oysters. Pearl is valued as a gemstone and is cultivated or harvested for jewellery. Pearls are formed inside the shell of certain bivalve mollusks. As a response to an irritating object inside its shell, the mollusk will deposit layers of calcium carbonate in the form of the minerals aragonite or calcite (both crystalline forms of calcium carbonate) held together by an organic horn-like compound called conchiolin. Before the beginning of the 20th Century, pearl hunting was the most common way of harvesting pearls. Divers manually pulled oysters from ocean floors and river bottoms and checked them individually for pearls.

Peat, also known as turf, is an accumulation of partially decayed vegetation or organic matter. Peat forms in wetland conditions, where flooding or stagnant water obstructs the flow of oxygen from the atmosphere, slowing the rate of decomposition. The peatland ecosystem is the most efficient carbon sink on the planet, because peatland plants capture carbon dioxide naturally released from the peat, maintaining an equilibrium. Over time, the formation of peat is often the first step in the geological formation of fossil fuels such as coal, particularly low-grade coal such as lignite. Peat is harvested as an important source of fuel in certain parts of the world.
TEXT.Italian: La torba è un accumulo di vegetazione parzialmente decomposta o di materia organica. La torba si forma in zone umide, dove inondazioni o acqua stagnante ostruiscono il flusso di ossigeno dall'atmosfera, rallentando il tasso di decomposizione. Una torbiera è il dissipatore di carbonio più efficiente del pianeta, perché le piante catturano l'anidride carbonica rilasciata naturalmente, mantenendo un equilibrio. Nel tempo, la formazione della torba è spesso il primo passo nella formazione geologica di combustibili fossili come il carbone, in particolare quello di bassa qualità come la lignite. La torba viene usata come importante fonte di combustibile in alcune parti del mondo.

TEXT.English: In clothing, fur is leather with the hair retained for its insulating properties. Fur has long served as a source of clothing for hominoids including the Neanderthal. Animal furs used in garments and trim may be dyed bright colors or to mimic exotic animal patterns, or shorn down to imitate the feel of a soft velvet fabric. The term "a fur" is often used to refer to a fur coat, wrap, or shawl.
TEXT.Italian: Una pelliccia è costituita da pelle con i peli attaccati, nota per le sue proprietà isolanti. Le pellicce sono state usate a lungo dagli ominidi per vestirsi, anche dagli uomini di Nenaderthal.Le pellicce possono essere tinte a piacere per ottenere qualsiasi disegno, oppure possono essere trattate per diventare come un soffice tessuto in velluto.

TEXT.English: A pencil is a writing implement or art medium usually constructed of a narrow, solid pigment core inside a protective casing. The case prevents the core from breaking, and also from marking the user's hand during use. Pencils create marks via physical abrasion, leaving behind a trail of solid core material that adheres to a sheet of paper or other surface. They are noticeably distinct from pens, which dispense liquid or gel ink that stain the light colour of the paper. Most pencil cores are made of graphite mixed with a clay binder, leaving grey or black marks that can be easily erased. Graphite pencils are used for both writing and drawing, and the result is durable: although writing can usually be removed with an eraser, it is resistant to moisture, most chemicals, ultraviolet radiation and natural aging. Other types of pencil core are less widely used. Charcoal pencils are mainly used by artists for drawing and sketching. Coloured pencils are sometimes used by teachers or editors to correct submitted texts but are more usually regarded as art supplies, especially those with waxy core binders that tend to smear on paper instead of erasing. Grease pencils have a softer crayon-like waxy core that can leave marks on smooth surfaces such as glass or porcelain.

A percussion instrument is any object which produces a sound when hit with an implement or when it is shaken, rubbed, scraped, or otherwise acted upon in a way that sets the object into vibration. The term usually applies to an object used in a rhythmic context or with musical intent.
TEXT.Italian: Uno strumento a percussione è qualsiasi oggetto in grado di produrre un suono quando viene colpito, sbattuto, grattato o toccato in qualsiasi modo tale da produrre una vibrazione. Questo oggetto viene solitamente usato in un contesto ritmico o per produrre musica.

TEXT.English: Perfume is a mixture of fragrant essential oils and/or aroma compounds, fixatives, and solvents used to give the human body, animals, objects, and living spaces a pleasant scent.
TEXT.Italian: Il prfoumo è una mistura di oli essenziali, fissativi e solventi usati per dare un buon odore al corpo umano, agli animali, agli oggetti o agli spazi abitati.

TEXT.English: Consumer electronics or home electronics are analog or digital electronic equipment intended for everyday use, typically in private homes. Consumer electronics include devices used for entertainment, communications, and home-office activities.
TEXT.Italian: L'elettronica di consumo comprende le apparecchiature elettroniche analogiche o digitali destinate all'uso quotidiano, in genere nelle case private. L'elettronica di consumo include dispositivi utilizzati per attività di intrattenimento, comunicazione e home-office.

TEXT.English: A personal hypercraft is a spacecraft designed for traveling between dimensions. It takes advantage of mass-production of interdimensional starcrafts, that transcend current understanding of physics or use interdimensional "shortcuts" or wormholes.
TEXT.Italian: Una ipernave personale, nota anche nave interdimensionale, è una navicella progettata per viaggiare tra le dimensioni. Sfrutta la produzione in serie di velivoli interdimensionali, che trascendono l'attuale comprensione della fisica o usano "scorciatoie" interdimensionali o tunnel spaziali.

TEXT.English: A spacecraft is a vehicle or machine designed to fly in outer space. Spacecraft are used for a variety of purposes, including communications, planet observation, exploration and colonization, meteorology, navigation, and transportation of humans and cargo. Orbital spacecrafts weren't recoverable well into early 21st century, when the first reusable spacecraft were successfully tested. Starting from 22nd century, they were increasingly designed to be cost-effectively mass-produced for the general public, thus increasing increases interplanetary migration and boosting solar system's tourism industry.
TEXT.Italian: Una navicella spaziale è una macchina progettata per volare nello spazio. Le navicelle vengono utilizzate per vari scopi, tra cui comunicazioni, osservazione, esplorazione e colonizzazione planetaria, meteorologia, navigazione e trasporto di esseri umani e merci. Le navicelle non erano inizialmente recuperabili fino all'inizio del XXI secolo, quando i primi veicoli spaziali riutilizzabili furono testati con successo. A partire dal XXII secolo, aumentò la progettazione in serie e a costi contenuti per il grande pubblico, aumentando così la migrazione interplanetaria e promuovendo l'industria del turismo nel sistema solare.

TEXT.English: A personal starcraft, also known as starship or interstellar spacecraft, is a spacecraft designed for traveling between planetary systems. It takes advantage of mass-production of faster-than-light starcrafts, that transcend current understanding of physics or use interdimensional "shortcuts" or wormholes.
TEXT.Italian: Una nave stellare personale, nota anche come astronave o astronave interstellare, è un'astronave progettata per viaggiare tra i sistemi planetari. Sfrutta la produzione in serie di velivoli più veloci della luce, che trascendono l'attuale comprensione della fisica o usano "scorciatoie" interdimensionali o tunnel spaziali.

TEXT.English: Petroleum products are materials derived from crude oil (petroleum) as it is processed in oil refineries. The largest share of oil products are the various grades of fuel oil and gasoline. Heavier (less volatile) fractions can also be used to produce asphalt, tar, paraffin wax, lubricating and other heavy oils. Refineries also produce other chemicals, some of which are used to produce plastics. Over 6,000 items are made from petroleum waste by-products, including fertilizers, floor coverings, perfumes, insecticides, petroleum jellies, soaps, vitamins and some essential amino-acids.
TEXT.Italian: I derivati del petrolio sono materiali derivati dal petrolio greggio trasformato nelle raffinerie. I principali derivati sono le varie gradazioni di benzina e altri oli combustibili. Le parti più pesanti (ossia meno volatili) possono essere invece usate per produrre asfalto, catrame, cera di paraffina, lubrificanti e altri oli pesanti. Le raffinerie producono anche altri prodotti chimici, alcuni dei quali vengono utilizzati per realizzare materie plastiche. Oltre 6.000 prodotti vengono realizzati con gli scarti delle raffinazioni, tra cui tra cui fertilizzanti, pavimentazioni (rivestimenti per pavimenti), profumi, insetticidi, gelatine di petrolio, saponi, vitamine e alcuni aminoacidi essenziali.

TEXT.English: Lophophora williamsii, better known by its common name Peyote (from the Nahuatl word peyotl), is a small, spineless cactus with psychoactive alkaloids, particularly mescaline. It is native to southwestern Texas and Mexico. It is found primarily in the Chihuahuan desert and in the states of Tamaulipas and San Luis Potosi among scrub, especially where there is limestone. Known for its psychoactive properties when ingested, it is used world wide as an entheogen and supplement to various transcendence practices, including meditation, psychonautics, and psychedelic psychotherapy. Peyote has a long history of ritualistic and medicinal use by indigenous Americans. It flowers from March through May, and sometimes as late as September. The flowers are pink, with thigmotactic anthers (like Opuntia).

A pharmaceutical drug, also referred to as a medicine or medication, can be loosely defined as any chemical substance - or product comprising such - intended for use in the medical diagnosis, cure, treatment, or prevention of disease. The word pharmaceutical comes from the Greek word Pharmakeia. The modern transliteration of Pharmakeia is Pharmacia.
TEXT.Polish: Lek - każda substancja, niezależnie od pochodzenia (naturalnego lub syntetycznego), nadająca się do bezpośredniego wprowadzania do organizmu w odpowiedniej postaci farmaceutycznej w celu osiągnięcia pożądanego efektu terapeutycznego, lub w celu zapobiegania chorobie, często podawana w ściśle określonej dawce. Lekiem jest substancja modyfikująca procesy fizjologiczne w taki sposób, że hamuje przyczyny lub objawy choroby, lub zapobiega jej rozwojowi. Określenie lek stosuje się też w stosunku do substancji stosowanych w celach diagnostycznych (np. metoklopramid w diagnostyce hiperprolaktynemii) oraz środków modyfikujących nie zmienione chorobowo funkcje organizmu (np. środki antykoncepcyjne).

TEXT.English: The phonograph, record player, or gramophone is a device introduced in 1877 for the recording and reproduction of sound recordings. The recordings played on such a device consist of waveforms that are engraved onto a rotating cylinder or disc. As the cylinder or disc rotates, a stylus or needle traces the waveforms and vibrates to reproduce the recorded sound waves.
TEXT.Polish: Fonograf - jedno z pierwszych urządzeń służących do zapisu i odtwarzania dźwięku, poprzednik gramofonu. Został skonstruowany przez Thomasa Alva Edisona. Edison swój wynalazek zademonstrował 29 listopada 1877 r., a opatentował 19 lutego 1878 r. W fonografie dźwięk zapisywany był przy pomocy igły na cylindrze zakładanym na walec napędzany początkowo korbką, później mechanizmem sprężynowym. Odtwarzanie przebiegało w analogiczny sposób. Igła (rylec) wykonana była z diamentu. Dźwięk zapisywano rzeźbiąc rowek na folii cynowej nawiniętej na stalowy walec.

TEXT.English: The pig has been domesticated for about 5,000 to 7,000 years and the animal is found across Europe, the Middle East, and extends in Asia as far as Indonesia and Japan. Pigs are one of the most intelligent animals, and some are even kept as pets. Pigs are reportedly more trainable than dogs and cats.
TEXT.French: Le cochon a été domestiqué il y a 5 à 7 000 ans. On le trouve dans toute l'Europe, au Moyen-Orient et jusqu'en Indonésie et au japon. Le cochon est un des animaux les plus intelligents, et il arrive parfois que l'on en fasse un animal de compagnie. Aux dires de certains, il serait même plus facile à dresser que le chat ou le chien.
TEXT.Italian: Il primo maiale addomesticato risale a circa 5.000 o 7.000 anni fa. Questo animale è comunemente diffuso in Europa, Medio Oriente, Asia e persino in Indonesia e Giappone. I maiali sono tra gli animali più intelligenti e possono essere addirittura degli animali da compagnia, poiché sono più facilmente addestrabili di cani e gatti.

TEXT.English: The pistachio a member of the cashew family, is a small tree originating from Central Asia and the Middle East. Pistachio trees can be found in regions of Iran, Syria, Lebanon, Turkey, Greece, Xinjiang (China), Tunisia, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, India, Egypt, Italy (Sicily), Uzbekistan, Afghanistan (especially in the provinces of Samangan and Badghis), and the United States, specifically in California. It is indigenous to the eastern Mediterranean (Cyprus and Turkey to Israel and Syria), Central Asia (Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Afghanistan, Tajikistan, and Kyrgyzstan) and Xinjiang. The tree produces seeds that are widely consumed as food.

Plasma is one of the four fundamental states of matter, and was first described by chemist Irving Langmuir in the 1920s. It consists of a gas of ions - atoms which have some of their orbital electrons removed – and free electrons. Plasma can be artificially generated by heating or subjecting a neutral gas to a strong electromagnetic field to the point where an ionized gaseous substance becomes increasingly electrically conductive. The resulting charged ions and electrons become influenced by long-range electromagnetic fields, making the plasma dynamics more sensitive to these fields than a neutral gas.

Plasteel is a steel-reinforced plastic substance referenced in multiple works in the Star Wars expanded universe, Warhammer 40,000, RimWorld, Subnautica, Stellaris, and other science fiction franchises.

A plastic material is any of a wide range of synthetic or semi-synthetic organic solids that are moldable. Plastics are typically organic polymers of high molecular mass, but they often contain other substances. They are usually synthetic, most commonly derived from petrochemicals, but many are partially natural.
TEXT.Italian: Un materiale plastico è un qualsiasi materiale sintetico o semi-sintetico che ha la capacità di piegarsi allo stato solido. La plastica è solitamente un polimero organico con elevata massa molecolare, ma spesso contiene altre sostanze; è solitamente sintetica, derivata dai prodotti petrolchimici, ma alcune varietà hanno anche componenti naturali.

TEXT.English: Platinum is a precious metal. Platinum was well-known to many ancient cultures, but most textbooks date the discovery of the metal to the eighteenth century when it was finally isolated in pure form. Archaeologists have discovered platinum artefacts originating from Egypt and Pre-Columbian America. The word platinum was derived from the Spanish platina or "little silver". Europeans became aware of platinum after Spanish Conquistadors brought it back with plundered gold and silver from the New World. Platinum became a very fashionable jewellery material during the nineteenth century. Many famous royal jewels including the Hope Diamond and the Star of Africa are mounted in platinum settings. During World War II, platinum use was banned in the US for any non-military purpose. This event suppressed consumer demand for platinum for decades, but it has made a strong resurgence in recent years as a premium jewellery material.

In narrative, pocket universes are fictional naturally or artificially-created universes that exist within the bounds of another universe. The term pocket universe is derived from its illustration in the actual universe where it is usually portrayed as an orb which would fit in a pocket.
Throughout human history, intentional application of poison has been used as a method of assassination, murder, suicide, and execution.
TEXT.Italian: Nel corso della storia il veleno è stato usato come metodi di assassinii, omicidi, suicidi ed esecuzioni.

TEXT.English: A pomegranate is a fruit-bearing deciduous shrub or small tree growing between 5 and 8 m tall. The pomegranate is native to the Caucasus, the Himalayas in north Pakistan and Northern India. It has been cultivated in the Caucasus since ancient times, and today, is widely cultivated throughout Iran, Azerbaijan, Armenia, Afghanistan, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Iraq, Egypt, China, Burma, Saudi Arabia, Israel, Jordan, the drier parts of southeast Asia, the Mediterranean region of Southern Europe, and tropical Africa. Introduced into Latin America and California by Spanish settlers in 1769, pomegranate is now cultivated in parts of California and Arizona for juice production

Porcelain is a ceramic material made by heating materials in a kiln to temperatures between 1,200 and 1,400 °C (2,200 and 2,600 °F). Properties associated with porcelain include low permeability and elasticity, considerable strength, hardness, toughness, whiteness, translucency and resonance, and a high resistance to chemical attack and thermal shock. Its manufacturing process is more demanding than that for earthenware and stoneware, and this is the reason it has usually been regarded as the most prestigious type of pottery. It combines well with both glazes and paint, and can be modelled very well, allowing a huge range of decorative treatments in tablewares, vessels and figurines. It also has many uses in technology and industry.
TEXT.Italian: La porcellana è un materiale ceramico costituito da materiali riscaldanti in un forno a temperature comprese tra 1.200 e 1.400 °C (2.200 e 2.600 °F). Le proprietà associate alla porcellana comprendono bassa permeabilità ed elasticità, notevole resistenza, durezza, tenacità, bianchezza, traslucenza e risonanza e un'alta resistenza agli attacchi chimici e agli shock termici. Il suo processo di produzione è più impegnativo di quello per terracotta e gres, ed è per questo che la porcellana viene generalmente considerata il tipo più prestigioso di ceramica. Si combina bene con smalti e vernici e può essere modellata molto bene, consentendo una vasta gamma di trattamenti decorativi in stoviglie, vasi e figurine. Ha anche molti usi nella tecnologia e nell'industria.

TEXT.English: Potash is any of various mined and manufactured salts that contain potassium in water-soluble form. The name derives from "pot ash", which refers to plant ashes soaked in water in a pot, the primary means of manufacturing the product before the industrial era.
TEXT.Polish: Potaż (historyczna, regionalna pisownia również potasz od niem. Potasche) - zanieczyszczona postać węglanu potasu K2CO3, rozpuszczalna w wodzie część popiołu pochodzącego ze spalania węgla drzewnego, zawierająca również zmienne ilości innych związków potasu. Nazwa potaż używana jest czasami na określenie dowolnego minerału zawierającego potas, zwłaszcza w krajach anglojęzycznych.

TEXT.English: A potato is a root vegetable and a starchy tuber. Potatoes were domesticated approximately 7,000-10,000 years ago in an area comprised between southern Peru and extreme northwestern Bolivia. Then they spread throughout the Americas, and were introduced to Europe in the second half of the 16th century. Today they are a staple food in many parts of the world (especially Northern and Eastern Europe), and an integral part of much of the world's food supply.
TEXT.Italian: Una patata è un ortaggio a radice e un tubero amidaceo. Le patate sono state addomesticate circa 7.000-10.000 anni fa in un'area compresa tra il Perù meridionale e la Bolivia nord-occidentale. Si diffusero successivamente in tutte le Americhe e, nella seconda metà del XVI secolo, furono introdotte in Europa. Oggi sono un alimento base in molte parti del mondo (specialmente in Europa settentrionale e orientale) e parte integrante di gran parte dell'offerta alimentare mondiale.

TEXT.English: A potato chip (known as a crisp in British English and Hiberno-English, and as either a chip or wafer in Indian English) is a thin slice of potato that is deep fried or baked until crunchy. Potato chips are commonly served as an appetizer, side dish, or snack. The basic chips are cooked and salted; additional varieties are manufactured using various flavorings and ingredients including seasonings, herbs, spices, cheeses, and artificial additives.
TEXT.German: Kartoffelchips, kurz Chips, in der Schweiz auch Pommes-Chips, in (Ost-)Österreich früher, heute nur noch gelegentlich, Rohscheiben genannt, sind in dünne Scheiben geschnittene und frittierte oder gebackene Kartoffeln. Sie dienen als Beilage oder Snack. Kartoffelchips gehören zu den beliebtesten Snacks und werden weltweit in vielen Geschmacksvarianten angeboten. In den USA werden sie Chips genannt, in Großbritannien und Irland jedoch Crisps, da dort Pommes frites Chips genannt werden (vgl. "Fish and Chips").
TEXT.Polish: Chipsy (lub czipsy) - popularna przekąska w postaci cienkich, osuszonych plastrów ziemniaków (najczęściej) lub innych warzyw, zazwyczaj obsmażonych w głębokim, gorącym tłuszczu. Ze względu na wysoką wartość energetyczną chipsów, do ich produkcji stosowane są również zamienniki tłuszczu oraz nowoczesne technologie produkcji, takie jak na przykład gotowanie z zastosowaniem mikrofal, a następnie spryskiwanie niewielką ilością oleju (bez zanurzenia w tłuszczu). Poszczególne smaki uzyskuje się dzięki doborowi przypraw i aromatów, rzadziej ziół.

TEXT.English: The invention of pottery was essential to the development of agricultural societies. To get the most out of seasonal crops and domesticated animals, a tribe needed sturdy, waterproof containers in which to store and protect surplus food. The discovery of the properties of clay, and the invention of the kiln and the potter's wheel made it possible to build such containers. The earliest examples of Western pottery date back to as early as 6500 BC. Most of the examples from this period were strictly utilitarian. Although use continued to be primarily practical, decorative pottery soon became a ritualistic and aesthetic art form in cultures all over the world. Some of the most impressive examples of artistic pottery comes from the pre-Columbian cultures of South America, and from the Ming dynasty in 14th century China.

Poultry are domesticated birds kept by humans for the eggs they produce, their meat, their feathers, or sometimes as pets. These birds are most typically members of the superorder Galloanserae (fowl), especially the order Galliformes (which includes chickens, quails and turkeys) and the family Anatidae, in order Anseriformes, commonly known as "waterfowl" and including domestic ducks and domestic geese. Poultry also includes other birds that are killed for their meat, such as the young of pigeons (known as squabs) but does not include similar wild birds hunted for sport or food and known as game. The word "poultry" comes from the French/Norman word poule, itself derived from the Latin word pullus, which means small animal.
TEXT.Polish: Drób - zbiorcze określenie udomowionych ptaków hodowanych ze względu na mięso, jaja, pierze oraz w celach dekoracyjnych. Do drobiu zalicza się między innymi kury, gęsi, indyki, kaczki, gołębie i perliczki. Do drobiu w sensie kulinarnym zaliczane bywają też potrawy z dzikich ptaków.

TEXT.English: A power tool is a tool that is actuated by an additional power source and mechanism other than the solely manual labour used with hand tools. The most common types of power tools use electric motors. Internal combustion engines and compressed air are also commonly used. Other power sources include steam engines, direct burning of fuels and propellants, or even natural power sources like wind or moving water. Tools directly driven by animal power are not generally considered power tools.
TEXT.Polish: Elektronarzędzia są to narzędzia zasilane prądem elektrycznym, najczęściej o napięciu 230 V. Ułatwiają prace, których wykonywanie narzędziami ręcznymi byłoby uciążliwe, czasochłonne lub niewygodne.

TEXT.English: The most common culinary species is the Indian fig opuntia (O. ficus-indica). Most culinary uses of the term "prickly pear" refer to this species. Prickly pears are also known as tuna (fruit) or nopal (paddle, plural nopales) from the Nahuatl word nopalli for the pads, or nostle, from the Nahuatl word nochtli for the fruit; or paddle cactus. Prickly pears typically grow with flat, rounded cladodes (also called platyclades) armed with two kinds of spines; large, smooth, fixed spines and small, hairlike prickles called glochids, that easily penetrate skin and detach from the plant. Many types of prickly pears grow into dense, tangled structures.
TEXT.German: Als Kaktusfeigen werden die Früchte der Kakteenart Opuntia ficus-indica bezeichnet. Es handelt sich um etwa 6 bis 10 cm lange, eiförmige oder längliche Früchte von gelbgrüner, oranger oder roter Farbe. Sie werden zusammen mit ihren essbaren Kernen verzehrt und haben einen süß-säuerlichen Geschmack. Man ist Kaktusfeigen entweder roh oder verarbeitet sie zu Marmelade oder Likör. Der Feigenkaktus stammt vermutlich aus Mexiko. Er ist die domestizierte Form von Opuntia megacantha, die nur noch über harmlose Dornen verfügt. Er war eine traditionelle Heilpflanze der Azteken und wird auch heute noch in der Volksmedizin verwendet, z.B. gegen Diabetes.

TEXT.English: Lumber or timber is wood that is used in any of its stages from felling through readiness for use as structural material for construction, or wood pulp for paper production. Lumber is supplied either rough or finished. Besides pulpwood, rough lumber is the raw material for furniture-making and other items requiring additional cutting and shaping. It is available in many species, usually hardwoods. Finished lumber is supplied in standard sizes, mostly for the construction industry, primarily softwood from coniferous species including pine, fir and spruce (collectively known as Spruce-pine-fir), cedar, hemlock, but also some hardwood, for high-grade flooring.
TEXT.German: Unter Edelholz versteht man Holzsorten, die sich durch bestimmte Eigenschaften von weit verbreiteten Hölzern wie Birke oder Buche unterscheiden. Dazu zählen eine ausdrucksvolle Farbgebung, markante Kontraste, schöne Maserungen und andere Auffälligkeiten, aber auch seltenes Vorkommen und dementsprechend hoher Wert oder eine besondere Resistenz gegen Schädlingsbefall. Letzten Endes kann die Einklassifizierung als Edelholz auch von einer rein subjektiven Wertschätzung herrühren. Einige bekannte Beispiele für Edelhölzer sind Mahagoni, Palisander, Teak und Ebenholz. Edelholz wird gern für Kunstwerke und Musikinstrumente verwendet. Außerdem werden häufig Furniere und Intarsien für Möbel und Automobilausstattung aus Edelhölzern hergestellt.
TEXT.Polish: Drewno - surowiec drzewny otrzymywany ze ściętych drzew i formowany przez obróbkę w różnego rodzaju sortymenty. Zajmuje przestrzeń pomiędzy rdzeniem a warstwą łyka i kory. Pod względem technicznym drewno jest naturalnym materiałem kompozytowym o osnowie polimerowej wzmacniany ciągłymi włóknami polimerowymi, którymi są podłużne komórki zorientowane jednoosiowo.

TEXT.English: Pumice, called pumicite in its powdered or dust form, is a volcanic rock that consists of highly vesicular rough textured volcanic glass, which may or may not contain crystals. It is typically light colored. Scoria is another vesicular volcanic rock that differs from pumice in having larger vesicles and thicker vesicle walls and being dark colored and denser.
TEXT.German: [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Bimsstein[COLOR_REVERT] oder kurz Bims ist ein stark poröses vulkanisches Gestein, das entsteht, wenn zähflüssige Lava bei Eruptionen durch Gase aufgeschäumt wird. Seine Farbe kann je nach Lavaart und Einschlüssen stark variieren. Es gibt nahezu schwarzen und weißen Bims, aber auch sämtliche Zwischentöne. Bimsstein geht nicht unter, sondern schwimmt auf Wasser, was an seinen vielen Poren und der daraus resultierenden sehr geringen Dichte liegt.[NEWLINE]Bims wurde bereits seit Vorzeiten in Kreta als Baumaterial, Opfergabe, Reinigungs- und Heilmittel und für diverse andere Zwecke eingesetzt. Das Gestein wird dort häufig über die Strömung von den vulkanischen Nachbarinseln angespült. In der Antike nutzte man den Bimsstein bereits zur Körperpflege, zum Schärfen von Schreibfedern und zum Glätten von Pergamentleder. Auch heute wird das Material noch vielseitig eingesetzt, z.B. für die Herstellung von Leichtbetonsteinen und Dämmstoffen und zum Filtern von Wasser. Bimsstein ist für den Stone-washed-Effekt von Jeans verantwortlich und stellt einen Grundstoff für viele gärtnerische Substrate dar.
TEXT.Polish: Pumeks (z łac. pumex), dawniej pemza - to wulkaniczna skała magmowa zbudowana z porowatego (ponad 50% porów) szkliwa wulkanicznego powstałego z silnie gazującej, pienistej lawy. Ma szklistą, drobnoziarnistą strukturę. Powstaje głównie z kwaśnych odmian lawy (riolitowej).

TEXT.English: A pumpkin is a gourd-like squash of the genus Cucurbita and the family Cucurbitaceae (which also includes gourds). It commonly refers to cultivars of any one of the species Cucurbita pepo, Cucurbita mixta, Cucurbita maxima, and Cucurbita moschata, and is native to North America. They typically have a thick, orange or yellow shell, creased from the stem to the bottom, containing the seeds and pulp.
TEXT.German: Die Kürbisse (Cucurbita) sind die namensgebende Pflanzengattung aus der Familie der Kürbisgewächse (Cucurbitaceae). Es handelt sich um krautige Pflanzen mit meist sehr großen, auffälligen Früchten (Panzerbeeren), die in Form und Farbe sehr stark variieren. Die Früchte der Wildform verfügen über eine sehr harte, holzige Schale und sind voll von Bitterstoffen, sodass ursprünglich nur die nahrhaften Samen verwendet wurden. Erst durch Auslese im Rahmen der Domestizierung wurde die Nutzung als Gemüse möglich. Anhand von Funden gilt heute als sicher, dass Kürbisse bereits zwischen 8000 und 10000 v.Chr. domestiziert wurden. Der Gartenkürbis hat seinen Ursprung im südlichen Nordamerika, während der Riesenkürbis aus Süd- und der Moschuskürbis aus Mittelamerika stammt.

TEXT.English: A punched card or punch card is a piece of stiff paper that can be used to contain digital data represented by the presence or absence of holes in predefined positions. Digital data can be used for data processing applications or, in earlier examples, used to directly control automated machinery. Punched cards were widely used through much of the 20th century in the data processing industry, where specialized and increasingly complex unit record machines, organized into semiautomatic data processing systems, used punched cards for data input, output, and storage. Many early digital computers used punched cards, often prepared using keypunch machines, as the primary medium for input of both computer programs and data. While punched cards are now obsolete as a storage medium, as of 2012, some voting machines still use punched cards to record votes.

The mineral pyrite, or iron pyrite, also known as fool's gold, is an iron sulfide with the formula FeS2. This mineral's metallic luster and pale brass-yellow hue give it a superficial resemblance to gold, hence the well-known nickname of fool's gold. The color has also led to the nicknames brass, brazzle, and Brazil, primarily used to refer to pyrite found in coal.
TEXT.Polish: Piryt - minerał żelaza z gromady siarczków, nadsiarczek żelaza(II), FeS2. Nazwa pochodzi od gr. pyr = ogień oraz pyrites = iskrzący, gdyż minerał ten iskrzy się pod wpływem uderzeń krzesiwa (krzemienia, twardego metalu).

TEXT.English: A qilin is a mythical chimerical creature known in Chinese and other East Asian cultures, said to appear with the imminent arrival or passing of a sage or illustrious ruler. Qilin generally have Chinese dragon-like features, most notably their heads, eyes with thick eyelashes, manes that always flow upward and beards. The body is fully or partially scaled and often shaped like an ox, deer, or horse. They are always shown with cloven hooves. Qilin are thought to be a symbol of luck, good omens, protection, prosperity, success, and longevity by the Chinese; they are also a symbol of fertility, and often depicted in decorations as bringing a baby to a family.
TEXT.Italian: Un qilin è una creatura mitica chimerica, nota nelle culture cinese e dell'Asia orientale, che si dice appaia all'arrivo o al passaggio imminente di un sovrano saggio o illustre. Generalmente, i lineamenti di un qilin sono simili a quelli di un dragone cinese, in particolare la testa, gli occhi con ciglia folte, le criniere che scorrono sempre verso l'alto e la barba. Il corpo è completamente o parzialmente coperto da scaglie, spesso a forma di bue, cervo o cavallo, e hanno sempre gli zoccoli. Si pensa che un qilin sia un simbolo di fortuna, buoni auspici, protezione, prosperità, successo e longevità da parte dei cinesi; sono anche un simbolo di fertilità e spesso raffigurati nelle decorazioni mentre portano un bimbo a una famiglia.

TEXT.English: A quantonium crystal is a powerful radioactive energy crystal that can fuel spaceships. It also has the significant contraindication of turning humans into giants.
TEXT.Italian: Un cristallo di quantonio è un potente cristallo di energia radioattiva che può alimentare astronavi. Ha anche la significativa controindicazione di trasformare gli umani in giganti.

TEXT.English: Quantum dots are tiny semiconductor particles, a few nanometers in size, having optical and electronic properties that differ from larger particles due to quantum mechanics. Quantum dots are sometimes referred to as artificial atoms, emphasizing their singularity, having bound, discrete electronic states, like naturally occurring atoms or molecules. Potential applications of quantum dots include single-electron transistors, solar cells, LEDs, lasers, single-photon sources, second-harmonic generation, quantum computing, and medical imaging.
TEXT.Italian: I punti quantici sono minuscole particelle semiconduttrici, di dimensioni di alcuni nanometri, con proprietà ottiche ed elettroniche che differiscono dalle particelle più grandi a causa della meccanica quantistica. I punti quantici sono talvolta chiamati "atomi artificiali", per enfatizzare la loro singolarità, avendo stati elettronici legati e discreti, come atomi o molecole presenti in natura. Le potenziali applicazioni dei punti quantici includono transistor a singolo elettrone, celle solari, LED, laser, sorgenti a singolo fotone, generazione di seconda armonica, calcolo quantico e imaging medico.

TEXT.English: A rabbit is a small mammal, found in several parts of the world. There are currently 305 known domestic breeds; the non-domesticated rabbits, known as hares, are generally larger and have more elongated ears and larger and longer hind legs. Domestication started during the Middle Ages, when rabbits were kept as livestock for their meat and fur, generating an increasingly wider selection. Many of these breeds were, starting with 19th century, also kept as pets. Rabbits are also often used as a symbol of fertility or rebirth in religion, and of vulnerability, sympathy and innocence in folklore and modern children's stories.
TEXT.Italian: Un coniglio è un piccolo mammifero, presenti in diverse parti del mondo. Attualmente ci sono 305 razze domestiche conosciute; le specie non addomesticate, note come lepri, sono generalmente più grandi e hanno orecchie più allungate e zampe posteriori più grandi e più lunghe. L'addomesticamento è iniziato durante il Medioevo, quando i conigli venivano allevati per la loro carne e la loro pelliccia, generando una selezione sempre più ampia. Molte di queste razze, a partire dal XIX secolo, iniziarono a essere allevate anche come animali domestici. I conigli sono spesso usati anche come simbolo di fertilità o rinascita nella religione e di vulnerabilità, simpatia e innocenza nel folklore e nelle moderne storie per bambini.

TEXT.English: A radio receiver, also known as radio, is an electronic device that receives radio waves and converts the information carried by them to a usable form. It is used with an antenna, that intercepts radio electromagnetic waves and converts them in such a way to allow the receiver to extract the desired information. The receiver uses electronic filters to separate the desired radio frequency signal from all the other signals picked up by the antenna, an electronic amplifier to increase the power of the signal for further processing, and finally recovers the desired information through demodulation. The most familiar type of radio receiver for most people is a broadcast radio receiver, which reproduces sound transmitted by radio broadcasting stations; however radio receivers are very widely used in televisions, cell phones, wireless modems and other components of communications, remote control, and wireless networking systems.
TEXT.Italian: Un ricevitore radio, noto anche come radio, è un dispositivo elettronico che riceve le onde radio e converte le informazioni trasportate da loro in una forma utilizzabile. Viene utilizzato con un'antenna, che intercetta le onde radio elettromagnetiche e le converte in modo che il ricevitore possa estrarre le informazioni desiderate. Il ricevitore utilizza filtri elettronici per separare il segnale di radiofrequenza desiderato da tutti gli altri segnali raccolti dall'antenna, un amplificatore elettronico per aumentare la potenza del segnale per un'ulteriore elaborazione e infine recuperare le informazioni desiderate attraverso la demodulazione. Il tipo più familiare di ricevitore radio per la maggior parte delle persone è un ricevitore radio che riproduce il suono trasmesso dalle stazioni radio; tuttavia i radioricevitori sono ampiamente utilizzati in televisori, telefoni cellulari, modem wireless e altri componenti di sistemi di comunicazione, controllo remoto e rete wireless.

TEXT.English: A rare-earth element (REE) or rare-earth metal (REM) is one of a set of seventeen chemical elements in the periodic table, i.e. cerium, dysprosium, erbium, europium, gadolinium, holmium, lanthanum, lutetium, neodymium, praseodymium, promethium, samarium, scandium, terbium, thulium, ytterbium, and yttrium. Despite their name, rare-earth elements are – with the exception of the radioactive promethium – relatively plentiful in Earth's crust. However, because of their geochemical properties, rare-earth elements are typically dispersed, therefore economically exploitable ore deposits are less common. Most of them are used for catalysts, high-performance magnets, alloys, glasses, and electronics. Some are also used to increase plant growth, productivity, and stress resistance seemingly without negative effects for human and animal consumption.
TEXT.Italian: Una terra rara o un metallo raro è uno di diciassette elementi chimici nella tavola periodica, ovvero cerio, disprosio, erbio, europeo, gadolinio, itterbio, ittrio, lantanio, lutezio, neodimio, olmio, praseodimio, promezio, samario, scandio, terbio e tulio. Nonostante il loro nome, le terre rare sono - con l'eccezione del prometio, che è radioattivo - relativamente abbondanti nella crosta terrestre. Tuttavia, a causa delle loro proprietà geochimiche, gli elementi delle terre rare sono in genere dispersi, quindi i depositi economicamente sfruttabili sono meno comuni. La maggior parte di essi viene utilizzata per catalizzatori, magneti ad alte prestazioni, leghe, vetri ed elettronica. Alcuni sono anche usati per aumentare la crescita, la produttività e la resistenza allo stress delle piante apparentemente senza effetti negativi per il consumo umano e animale.

TEXT.English: Raw fish generally refers to any type of uncooked muscle tissue of aquatic creatures used for food. Raw fish present a higher risk of disease from ingesting pathogens than cooked fish.
TEXT.Italian: Il pesce crudo è qualsiasi tipo di tessuto muscolare crudo di una creatura acquatica. Il pesce crudo presenta un rischio più elevato di malattie dovute ad agenti patogeni rispetto al pesce cotto.

TEXT.English: Raw meat generally refers to any type of uncooked muscle tissue of an animal used for food. This term refers specifically to mammalian flesh, or to any animal which is not a bird (in this case, the preferred term is "poultry") or an aquatic creature (in this case, the preferred term is "seafood"). Raw meat present a higher risk of disease from ingesting pathogens than cooked meat.
TEXT.Italian: La carne cruda è qualsiasi tipo di tessuto muscolare crudo di un animale usato per il cibo. Questo termine si riferisce specificamente alla carne di mammiferi o di qualsiasi animale che non sia un uccello (in questo caso, il termine preferito è "pollame") o una creatura acquatica (in questo caso, il termine preferito è "pescato"). La carne cruda presenta un rischio più elevato di malattie dovute ad agenti patogeni rispetto alla carne cotta.

TEXT.French: Objets à figures rouges et noires

TEXT.English: Red and black ceramics were one of the most important styles of figural Greek vase painting. This process was developed in Athens around 520 BC, remained in use until the late 3rd century BC, and replaced the previously dominant style of black-figure vase painting within a few decades. For a long time, they dominated the market for fine ceramics in much of the Mediterranean basin, with Etruria being the only non-Greek area to develop an autonomous "school". Their images provide evidence for the exploration of Greek and Etruscan cultural history, everyday life, iconography, and mythology.
TEXT.Italian: Le ceramiche rosse e nere hanno rappresentato uno degli stili più importanti della pittura figurale greca su vaso. Questo processo si sviluppò ad Atene intorno al 520 a.C., rimase in uso fino alla fine del III secolo a.C. e rimpiazzò lo stile precedentemente dominante della pittura a figure nere nel giro di pochi decenni. Per molto tempo, hanno dominato il mercato delle ceramiche di pregio in gran parte del bacino del Mediterraneo; l'Etruria fu l'unica area non greca a sviluppare una "scuola" autonoma. Le loro immagini forniscono prove dell'esplorazione della storia culturale, della vita quotidiana, dell'iconografia e della mitologia greca ed etrusca.

TEXT.English: In polyphyletic botany, a reed is a type of tall, grass-like plant of wet places, it is also very flamable; the namesake vegetation of reed beds.
TEXT.German: Schilfrohr (Phragmites australis oder Phragmites communis) oder kurz Schilf ist eine weltweit verbreitete Sumpfpflanze, die zu den Süßgräsern gehört. Schilfhalme können bis zu 4 m hoch werden. Sie bilden rispenförmige Blütenstände aus, die bis zu 50 cm groß sein können. Schilf verdrängt bei günstigen Nährstoffangebot andere Wildgräser und -kräuter, weshalb an stehenden und langsam fließenden Gewässern in der Regel natürliche Monokulturen entstehen. Schilf kann vielseitig verwendet werden. Als Naturbaustoff eignet es sich besonders in Form von Reet als Dachabdeckung, es kam aber auch beim Bau früher Schiffe zum Einsatz. Von Vorteil war hierbei der hohe Gehalt an Kieselsäure, durch den es eine brandhemmende Wirkung hatte. Schilf kann als Gemüse verzehrt und aus seinen getrockneten Wurzeln kann ein Mehl zum Brotbacken gewonnen werden. In der Antike war es als Schreibrohr jahrhundertelang das wichtigste Schreibgerät. Heute wird Schilf als Dämmstoff, in Pflanzenkläranlagen und als natürlicher Bodenfilter verwendet.
TEXT.Polish: Trzcina (Phragmites L.) - rodzaj roślin należący do rodziny wiechlinowatych. Należy do niego 4-5 gatunków. W Polsce w środowisku naturalnym rośnie jeden tylko gatunek - trzcina pospolita (Phragmites australis), jest to zarazem gatunek typowy rodzaju.

TEXT.English: A refrigerator (colloquially fridge) is a common household appliance that consists of a thermally insulated compartment and a heat pump (mechanical, electronic, or chemical) that transfers heat from the inside of the fridge to its external environment so that the inside of the fridge is cooled to a temperature below the ambient temperature of the room. Refrigeration is an essential food storage technique in developed countries. Lower temperatures in a confined volume lowers the reproduction rate of bacteria, so the refrigerator reduces the rate of spoilage.
TEXT.German: Ein Kühlschrank ist ein elektrisches oder gasbetriebenes schrankförmiges Gerät, das die Temperatur in seinem Inneren selbstständig niedrig hält. Mittels eines üblicherweise an der Rückseite befindlichen und per Temperaturregler geregelten Kühlaggregates wird das Kühlschrankinnere gekühlt. Kühlschränke finden Verwendung für die Lagerung von Nahrungsmitteln, Medikamenten, Chemikalien usw. Durch die niedrigere Temperatur laufen chemische Reaktionen und biologische Prozesse, die beispielsweise Lebensmittel ungenießbar und Medikamente unbrauchbar werden lassen, langsamer ab.
TEXT.Polish: Chłodziarka (zwycz. lodówka) - urządzenie (maszyna cieplna), którego zadaniem jest obniżenie temperatury środowiska chłodzonego, kosztem doprowadzonej energii. W chłodziarkach absorpcyjnych energia dostarczana jest w postaci ciepła, natomiast w pozostałych (sprężarkowych, strumienicowych, termoelektrycznych) w postaci pracy. Chłodzonym czynnikiem może być powietrze, woda lub inny czynnik pośredniczący (chłodziwo).

TEXT.English: An artificial organ is a man-made device that is implanted or integrated into a human to replace a natural organ, for the purpose of restoring a specific function or a group of related functions so the patient may return to as normal a life as possible. The replaced function doesn't necessarily have to be related to life support, but often is. Implied by this definition is the fact that the device must not be continuously tethered to a stationary power supply, or other stationary resources, such as filters or chemical processing units. (Periodic rapid recharging of batteries, refilling of chemicals, and/or cleaning/replacing of filters, would exclude a device from being called an artificial organ.) Thus a dialysis machine, while a very successful and critically important life support device that completely replaces the duties of a kidney, is not an artificial organ. At this time an efficient, self-contained artificial kidney has not become available.
TEXT.German: Ein künstliches Organ ist ein von Menschen gemachtes Gerät das einem Menschen implantiert wird, um ein natürliches Organ zu ersetzen. Dies dient dem Zweck eine spezifische Funktion oder eine Gruppe verwandter Funktionen wiederherzustellen um dem Patient ein normales Leben zu ermöglichen. Das ersetzte Organ muss dabei nicht zwangsläufig eine lebenserhaltene Funktion erfüllen, tut dies aber meistens. Diese Definition impliziert dass das Gerät nicht dauerhaft an eine stationäre Energiequelle oder andere stationäre Ressourcen wie Filter, angeschlossen sein muss. (Das schnelle periodische Aufladen von Batterien, nachfüllen von Chemikalien und/oder säubern/ersetzen von Filtern würde ein Gerät nicht als künstliches Organ klassifizieren.) Somit ist eine Dialysemaschine, obwohl sie ein sehr erfolgreiches und notwendiges Gerät zur Lebenserhaltung ist, dass die Aufgaben der Niere komplett erfüllt, kein künstliches Organ sein. Zur Zeit sind effiziente, selbstversorgene Kunstnieren nicht verfügbar.

TEXT.English: Replicators were advanced robots capable of reproducing themselves indefinitely, consuming all available resources in an area to create more of themselves. The Replicators were created at an unspecified time in the past on a Human world where an android called Reese was created. This machine had a childlike personality and was feared by the natives of the planet. In order to keep herself amused, she created the Replicators which were to be her toys. As the population of the world grew more fearful of Reese and the Replicators, she began to teach the machines to protect her and themselves. In order to accomplish this, they began the process of self replication. The Replicators grew too large in number, and Reese herself began to lose the ability to control them
